summary: This FBI document from September 2010 details an obstruction of justice investigation into a former house manager/butler of Jeffrey Epstein who attempted to sell a list of additional victims for $50,000. It also requests the New York Division to interview architect Robert Couturier, who reported designing a bedroom for teenage girls at Epstein's Virgin Islands residence and seeing Epstein with an underage girl.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The document details the prior child prostitution investigation against him, his non-prosecution agreement, guilty plea to state offenses, and his status as a defendant in civil suits by victims. He is the employer of the house manager and the client of Robert Couturier.

persons.name: Robert Couturier
persons.context: Hired by Epstein for remodeling and design services at his Virgin Islands residence. He reportedly designed a bedroom with pink furnishings and bunk beds appropriate for teenage girls and observed Epstein in the company of what appeared to be an underage girl. May be involved in civil litigation with Epstein.

connections.description: Epstein hired Couturier for remodeling and design services at his Virgin Islands residence.
The document states Epstein and Couturier may be currently involved in civil litigation against one another for services Couturier provided.

events.title: Miami Division Investigation of Epstein Begins
events.description: The FBI's Miami Division began investigating Jeffrey Epstein for child prostitution.

events.title: Obstruction of Justice Case Opened
events.description: Miami Division opened an obstruction of justice case against Epstein's former house manager/butler for attempting to sell a list of additional victims.

events.title: Attempted Sale of Victim List
events.description: Epstein's former house manager/butler attempted to sell information about additional victims to an Undercover Employee (UCE) for $50,000.

events.title: Epstein Completes Community Supervision
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein completed his state-mandated community supervision as a registered sex offender.

keyFacts: Epstein's former house manager/butler attempted to sell a list of additional victims not previously disclosed to law enforcement for $50,000 to an undercover FBI employee in November 2009.
Architect Robert Couturier reported designing a bedroom in Epstein's Virgin Islands residence with pink furnishings and bunk beds 'appropriate for teenage girls.'
Couturier also reported seeing Jeffrey Epstein in the company of what appeared to be an underage girl, though the location (Virgin Islands or Palm Beach) was unclear.
The FBI's New York Division was requested to interview Couturier regarding his work for Epstein and his observations of potential underage girls.
Epstein and Couturier may have been involved in civil litigation against each other related to the design services at the time of this document.
